section_1_sacred_text.original_script: ἀλλὰ ἀναστὰς κατάβηθι καὶ πορεύου σὺν αὐτοῖς μηδὲν διακρινόμενος, ὅτι ἐγὼ ἀπέσταλκα αὐτούς.
section_1_sacred_text.faithful_direct_translation: But, having arisen, go down and journey with them, discriminating nothing, because I have sent them.
section_1_sacred_text.standalone_english_translation: So get up and go downstairs. Do not hesitate to go with them, for I have sent them.
section_1_sacred_text.amplified_narrative_translation: On the contrary, you must now stand up, go down from this roof, and journey with these men, ceasing all your internal doubt and making no distinctions based on your prejudices, because it is I Myself who have commissioned and sent them with abiding authority.

literal_primary_filter: The setting is a command given by the Holy Spirit directly to the Apostle Peter.
Peter is on the flat rooftop of a house in the port city of Joppa, having just experienced a perplexing vision.
The Spirit issues three direct commands: Arise, go down, and go with the men who have arrived.
A crucial qualifying command is given: to go without hesitation, doubt, or making any prejudiced distinctions.
The ultimate reason and authority for this command is stated: God Himself has sent these men.
prophetic_typology_intertextuality: The command directly confronts the Old Testament Levitical laws of clean and unclean (Leviticus 11; Deuteronomy 14), which formed the basis for Jewish separation.
Peter's reluctance is a 'Type' of Jonah's reluctance to go to the Gentile city of Nineveh (Jonah 1:1-3), representing Israel's resistance to its mission to the nations.
The inclusion of the Gentiles is the Antitype, the fulfillment of prophetic promises that Israel would be a 'light to the Gentiles' (Isaiah 49:6).

This event is the historic, apostolic realization of Jesus's own ministry to Gentiles, such as the Roman Centurion (Matthew 8:5-13), and His direct teaching that He had 'other sheep that are not of this fold' (John 10:16).
It provides the foundational precedent for the Jerusalem Council's later decision (Acts 15) and Paul's entire ministry.
This moment historically breaks down the 'dividing wall of hostility' that Paul would later describe in his theology (Ephesians 2:14).
linguistic_mechanics_names: The command begins with the strong adversative [ἀλλὰ] (alla, 'but, on the contrary'), sharply contrasting the Spirit's will with Peter's internal hesitation.
The first action, [ἀναστὰς] (anastas, 'having arisen'), is an aorist participle, implying a decisive, completed act of getting up before the journey can begin.
The command to descend, [κατάβηθι] (katabēthi), is a direct, forceful aorist imperative.
The command to travel, [πορεύου] (poreuou), is a present imperative, suggesting the initiation of a process or journey.
The most critical phrase is [μηδὲν διακρινόμενος] (mēden diakrinomenos), meaning 'making no distinction' or 'without wavering/doubting'.
The verb διακρίνω (diakrinō) encompasses both internal doubt and external discrimination, commanding Peter to cease his internal debate and suspend his social-religious judgment.
The authority for the command is grounded in the emphatic pronoun [ἐγὼ] (egō, 'I') and the perfect tense verb [ἀπέσταλκα] (apestalka, 'I have sent').
The perfect tense signifies that their sending by God is a past, completed act with ongoing results; they arrive as divinely commissioned envoys.
This verb, ἀποστέλλω (apostellō), is the root of the word 'apostle', elevating the divine mission of these Gentiles.
Peter, whose name is [Πέτρος] (Petros, 'Rock'), is being used as the foundational apostle to open the door of faith to the Gentiles.
The men were sent by Cornelius [Κορνήλιος] (Kornēlios), a Roman name derived from 'cornu' (horn), a symbol of strength and power, representing the inclusion of the Roman world.
literary_devices: The passage uses a rhetorical structure of rapid, successive imperatives (Arise! Go down! Go!) to convey urgency and absolute divine authority, leaving no room for argument.
This series of commands creates a powerful narrative momentum, propelling a hesitant Peter into a world-changing action.
numerical_gematria_significance: The vision preceding this command was repeated three times (Acts 10:16), a number signifying divine emphasis, completeness, and witness, ensuring Peter could not dismiss it.
This threefold vision serves to correct Peter's earlier threefold denial of Christ (John 21:15-17), restoring him now as the agent of a bold new inclusion.
There were three men sent from Cornelius (Acts 10:7, 19), mirroring the divine pattern of the vision and confirming the source of their mission.
historical_context_chronology: The event is conservatively dated to circa AD 40-41.
This falls within the reign of the Roman Emperor Caligula or the early reign of Claudius.
Peter was staying in the house of 'Simon, a tanner' (Acts 10:6).
Tanning was a ritually unclean profession for Jews due to contact with dead animals, so Peter's lodging there already indicates a softening of his adherence to rabbinic tradition.
socio_political_matrix: The Roman Empire governed Judea, with Caesarea Maritima serving as the administrative capital and military headquarters.
Cornelius was a centurion of the 'Italian Cohort,' an auxiliary unit of the Roman army likely composed of Roman citizens from Italy, representing the ruling military power.
The social barrier between Jews and Gentiles was immense; entering a Gentile's house or eating with them was considered defiling by strict Jewish tradition (Acts 10:28).
Cornelius is described as a 'God-fearer,' a recognized class of Gentiles who worshipped the God of Israel but had not become full proselytes through circumcision.
The Spirit's command directly overturns one of the most powerful social, ethnic, and religious taboos of the day.
geospatial_data_physical_geography: The event occurs in Joppa (modern Jaffa, a part of Tel Aviv-Yafo, Israel).
Joppa is an ancient port city on the Mediterranean coast, built on a prominent hill rising from the coastal plain, with an altitude of up to 40 meters (131 feet).
Peter was on the rooftop (Acts 10:9), a common feature of homes in the ancient Near East used for prayer, work, and escaping the heat, providing a high and separate place for his vision.
The command 'go down' (κατάβηθι) was therefore a literal instruction to descend from the roof to the ground floor or courtyard to meet the visitors.
archaeological_confirmation: Jaffa is one of the oldest continuously inhabited port cities in the world, and extensive archaeological excavations confirm its layout and importance in the Roman period.
Inscriptions and military records confirm the existence of Roman auxiliary cohorts, including Italian cohorts, stationed throughout the empire, validating the description of Cornelius's unit.

While the specific house of Simon the Tanner has not been identified, the description of a house 'by the sea' (Acts 10:6) is topographically and historically consistent with the needs of a tannery in ancient Joppa.
aggregate_perspective_analogia_scriptura: This verse marks a pivotal turning point in redemptive history, second only to the Resurrection and Pentecost.
The Holy Spirit directly intervenes to dismantle the primary socio-theological barrier preventing the gospel's global expansion.

God's command to Peter, 'make no distinction,' is the apostolic key that unlocks the door for the fulfillment of the Abrahamic Covenant: that through Abraham's seed 'all the families of the earth shall be blessed' (Genesis 12:3).
The divine declaration, 'I have sent them,' reframes evangelism: it is not merely a human endeavor, but our cooperation with a work already initiated by God.
This single event provides the theological and historical justification for the church's universal mission, confirming that in Christ there is 'neither Jew nor Greek' (Galatians 3:28).

application_summary: Listen for God's specific instructions, especially those that challenge your personal comforts, cultural traditions, or ingrained prejudices.
When God directs you to engage with someone, obey immediately and without internal debate ('making no distinction').
Recognize that the people God places in your path are not random encounters; they are divinely sent ('I have sent them').
Your role is to get up, go to them, and share the truth without judgment, trusting that God has already been at work in their lives.
Actively identify and dismantle any 'dividing wall' in your own heart—be it racial, economic, political, or social—that prevents you from seeing others as people God has sent you to.
